intro: Glossorhyncha subalpina, commonly known as the alpine glossorhyncha, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, and the flowers are usually white or pale green, arranged in umbels. Due to its specific habitat requirements, Glossorhyncha subalpina is considered a rare and endangered species in many parts of its range.
